Award.AwardTitle: SG: Collaborative Research: The Role of Watering Holes in Concentrating Parasites in a Changing Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Watering points draw together an enormous range of wildlife and domestic animals, forming a direct interface for disease transmission. Understanding the degree to which water aggregates animals and their parasites across seasons and climate gradients is particularly important in light of current climate change and water instability, particularly in the East African tropical savanna. This region is home to some of the world's most charismatic wildlife species, but it is also a disease hotspot that is currently undergoing continued development and expanded ranching and cattle practices in wildlife zones. This project will seek to quantify the effect of watering points on parasite density, as mediated by animal movement, and to understand how climate and host community play a role in disease risk at water points across the landscape.

The project entails four distinct components that integrate extensive observational surveys, experimental manipulations, and mathematical modelling. The first component involves a survey of 20 dams and control sites across a steep rainfall gradient in Laikipia County, central Kenya. Dung surveys, tick drags, camera trapping, vegetation surveys, and soil and water analyses will be used to determine the density of animals and their parasites at both watering holes and control sites over rainfall seasons. The second component will utilize paired water pans used by wildlife and cattle: one water pan in each pair will be drained for two rainfall seasons before being refilled, and all surveys listed above will be repeated for this experiment. The third component will utilize animal exclosure plots at water sources to determine the effect of large mammal loss on parasite density in the landscape. Finally, mathematical models parameterized with field data will be used to simulate the transmission of fecal-oral parasites over different climates and seasons for a range of hosts. The effect of water availability and distribution on animal movement and disease prevalence will be tested, providing valuable insight to both land managers and scientists on the complex system of water, hosts, and parasites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Motivation

Humans disturb the planet in many ways that strongly affect wildlife and human disease transmission. Because transmission hotspots are critically important aspects of many diseases, any disturbance at these hotspots has great potential to affect overall disease dynamics. Despite their importance, spatial hotspots and their human-driven changes have been relatively poorly studied in the context of human-wildlife disease transmission. Water sources are likely to be important spatial hotspots in most arid terrestrial systems, as they draw together wildlife, domestic animals, and humans in high numbers around a shared resource (water). However increased surface water use and changing global environmental conditions threaten to rapidly change the abundance and distribution of these water sources, providing an important and pressing example of ways that changing hotspots affect disease dynamics.

Findings

In this study, we used observational and experimental data to investigate the effects of water sources on plants, herbivores, and gastrointestinal parasites across an aridity gradient in a semi-arid savanna system in central Kenya.  As hypothesized, we found that water sources caused dramatic increases in the abundance of both wild and domestic herbivores (three times higher activity across all herbivore species) and their gastrointestinal parasites (up to 150 times as many). However, the effects varied dramatically by species: elephants, cattle, and their parasites showed the strongest increases near water, while less water dependent species and their parasites showed much smaller increases around water. Not surprisingly, the effect of water in heightening animal and parasite aggregations was stronger in more arid systems, suggesting that drying environments may lead to increased parasite transmission at these hotspots. These findings emphasize the importance of surface water sources in landscape-level parasite transmission, especially as Earth?s surface experiences ongoing climate and surface water changes. 

In addition to changes in parasite abundance, we also investigated how parasite sharing networks would likely change risk across species. Specifically, we investigated gastrointestinal parasite communities in 18 large herbivore species of East Africa using DNA metabarcoding. We then linked data on parasite abundance and parasite sharing to data from an 8000-volunteer citizen science project measuring herbivore activity from camera traps to estimate parasite transmission near water relative to dry sites. We found that due to their abundance, degree of aggregation around water, and ability to share parasites, cattle were very important as drivers of gastrointestinal parasite transmission for other herbivore species at water sources. Together, these findings demonstrate the importance of water sources for understanding and predicting disease dynamics in humans, wildlife, and domesticated animals that live in increasingly dry landscapes and will be informative for management of disease transmission in changing landscapes.

Outreach and Broader Impacts

We have presented these results at numerous ecological conferences, and continue to communicate our findings. The project provided training for 5 undergraduates who traveled to Kenya to engage in field work, 10 undergraduates who assisted in our citizen science project, 1 graduate student, and 3 research assistants in the US and Kenya. Thus far, in addition to presentations at 6 major ecology conferences, our research has resulted in three published journal articles, one completed dissertation, one article in submission, and three articles and a book chapter in final stages for submission.

Throughout the course of this project, we engaged scientists, students, managers, and members of the public in Kenya and the United States, providing educational services in both countries. In Kenya, we co-taught a parasite workshop at the National Museums of Kenya, presented and designed activities to engage multiple student groups that ranged from 5th grade to masters level, shared our research with over 100 local ranchers and stakeholders, and presented findings at the National Commission for Science, Technology, and Innovation conference in Nairobi. We also worked with students from Daraja academy, a school dedicated to increasing educational opportunities for underserved girls, designing activities to give students hands-on experience in field research and parasitology. 

In the United States, we brought our research to classrooms, girl scout troops, and more via the Skype a Scientist program. We have met with groups ranging from 6 years of age to adult in an effort to increase dialogue about our research, the importance of the scientific method, and pathways to science for groups of all backgrounds. We also worked with the Kids in Nature Program to support education and exposure to some of these concepts for 135 5th graders primarily from traditionally underserved communities.
